message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Swarm Robotic Behaviors and Current Applications
Paper Abstract: In swarm robotics multiple robots collectively solve problems by forming advantageous structures and behaviors similar to the ones observed in natural systems, such as swarms of bees, birds, or fish. However, the step to industrial applications has not yet been made successfully. Literature is light on real-world swarm applications that apply actual swarm algorithms. Typically, only parts of swarm algorithms are used which we refer to as basic swarm behaviors. In this paper we collect and categorize these behaviors into spatial organization, navigation, decision making, and miscellaneous. This taxonomy is then applied to categorize a number of existing swarm robotic applications from research and industrial domains. Along with the classification, we give a comprehensive overview of research platforms that can be used for testing and evaluating swarm behavior, systems that are already on the market, and projects that target a specific market. Results from this survey show that swarm robotic applications are still rare today. Many industrial projects still rely on centralized control, and even though a solution with multiple robots is employed, the principal idea of swarm robotics of distributed decision making is neglected. We identified mainly following reasons: First of all, swarm behavior emerging from local interactions is hard to predict and a proof of its eligibility for applications in an industrial context is difficult to provide. Second, current communication architectures often do not match requirements for swarm communication, which often leads to a system with a centralized communication infrastructure. Finally, testing swarms for real industrial applications is an issue, since deployment in a productive environment is typically too risky and simulations of a target system may not be sufficiently accurate. In contrast, the research platforms present a means for transforming swarm robotics solutions from theory to prototype industrial systems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Here's an overview of swarm behavior based on the search results:

## Definition and Core Concepts

Swarm intelligence (SI) is the collective behavior of decentralized, self-organized systems, natural or artificial.(no content)This is an emergent behaviour governed by local rules that are followed by individuals and does not involve any central coordination.

## Natural Examples

Swarm behavior occurs across many species:

- **Honey Bees**: Swarming is a honey bee colony's natural means of reproduction. In the process of swarming, a single colony splits into two or more distinct colonies.

- **Birds**: Flocking is the behavior exhibited when a group of birds, called a flock, are foraging or in flight.

- **Insects**: Midges form swarms, dancing in the air. Swarming serves multiple purposes, including the facilitation of mating by attracting females to approach the swarm.

- **Plants**: Plant roots display observable swarm behavior, growing in patterns that exceed the statistical threshold for random probability. The primary function of plant roots is the uptake of soil nutrients, and it is this purpose which drives swarm behavior.

## Underlying Mechanisms

Stigmergy is a mechanism of indirect coordination, through the environment, between agents or actions. The principle is that the trace left in the environment by an individual action stimulates the performance of a succeeding action by the same or different agent.

## Computational Applications

The application of swarm principles to robots is called swarm robotics while swarm intelligence refers to the more general set of algorithms.

Web search results for query: "Navigation algorithm"

Links: [{"title":"Navigational algorithms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigational_algorithms"},{"title":"A* search algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/A*_search_algorithm"},{"title":"Navigation mesh - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigation_mesh"},{"title":"Robot navigation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_navigation"},{"title":"Satellite navigation solution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Satellite_navigation_solution"},{"title":"Motion planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigation_problem"},{"title":"Dijkstra's algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dijkstra's_algorithm"},{"title":"Pathfinding - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pathfinding"},{"title":"Layered costmaps - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Layered_costmaps"},{"title":"Navigation function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Navigation_function"}]

Here's an overview of navigation algorithms based on the search results:

## What are Navigation Algorithms?

Navigation algorithms are computational procedures used for different types of navigation across various domains. The term encompasses several different applications:

### Traditional Navigation Algorithms
Advanced navigation algorithms include piloting and astronomical navigation: loxodromia and orthodromia.(no content)Navigational algorithms are the quintessence of the executable software on portable calculators or smartphones as an aid to the art of navigation.

### Pathfinding and Robot Navigation
Pathfinding or pathing is the search, by a computer application, for the shortest route between two points. Key algorithms in this area include:

- **A* Algorithm**: A* (pronounced "A-star") is a graph traversal and pathfinding algorithm that is used in many fields of computer science due to its completeness, optimality, and optimal efficiency.(no content)A* achieves better performance by using heuristics to guide its search.

- **Dijkstra's Algorithm**: Dijkstra's algorithm is an algorithm for finding the shortest paths between nodes in a weighted graph, which may represent, for example, a road network.

- **Navigation Mesh**: A navigation mesh is a collection of two-dimensional convex polygons (a polygon mesh) that define which areas of an environment are traversable by agents.

### Robot Navigation
Robot navigation means the robot's ability to determine its own position in its frame of reference and then to plan a path towards some goal location.

Based on the search results, here's an overview of robot communication:

## Human-Robot Communication

The goal is to build intuitive and easy communication with robots through speech, gestures, and facial expressions.(no content)Much of active human-robot interaction development depends on natural language processing, with many aspects being continuations of human communications research.

## Inter-Robot Communication

Robots possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities, such as wireless transmission systems, like radio frequency or infrared.(no content)The initial goal of studying swarm robotics was to test whether the concept of stigmergy could be used as a method for robots to indirectly communicate and coordinate with each other.(no content)Robots can coordinate to retrieve an object to a certain location without the use of explicit communication, similar to how ants coordinate their efforts in nature.

## Advanced Communication Technologies

Quantum robotics is an interdisciplinary field that investigates the intersection of robotics and quantum mechanics, exploring applications of quantum phenomena such as quantum entanglement, including quantum communication in multi-agent cooperative robotic scenarios and the integration of quantum devices in robotic systems.

## Research Focus

Some researchers have created feedback systems that allow human users to subconsciously communicate through brainwave activity whether a robot has made a mistake, and using wearable body sensors, developed systems that enable users to more smoothly control drones and work with robots to lift and transport goods.

Robots possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities, such as wireless transmission systems, like radio frequency or infrared.(no content)The initial goal of studying swarm robotics was to test whether the concept of stigmergy could be used as a method for robots to indirectly communicate and coordinate with each other.(no content)Robots can coordinate to retrieve an object to a certain location without the use of explicit communication, similar to how ants coordinate their efforts in nature.

## Advanced Communication Technologies

Quantum robotics is an interdisciplinary field that investigates the intersection of robotics and quantum mechanics, exploring applications of quantum phenomena such as quantum entanglement, including quantum communication in multi-agent cooperative robotic scenarios and the integration of quantum devices in robotic systems.

## Research Focus

Some researchers have created feedback systems that allow human users to subconsciously communicate through brainwave activity whether a robot has made a mistake, and using wearable body sensors, developed systems that enable users to more smoothly control drones and work with robots to lift and transport goods.

Web search results for query: "Decision making"

Links: [{"title":"Decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making"},{"title":"Consensus decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Consensus_decision-making"},{"title":"Decision fatigue - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision_fatigue"},{"title":"Decision-making under deep uncertainty - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decision-making_under_deep_uncertainty"},{"title":"Military Decision Making Process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Military_Decision_Making_Process"},{"title":"Memory and decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Memory_and_decision-making"},{"title":"Models of judicial decision making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Models_of_judicial_decision_making"},{"title":"Data-informed decision-making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Data-informed_decision-making"},{"title":"Judgment and Decision Making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Judgment_and_Decision_Making"},{"title":"Optimal decision - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_decision"}]

## Web Search Results for "Decision Making"

I've found comprehensive information about decision-making. Here are the key findings:

### Definition and Core Concept

Decision-making is regarded as the cognitive process resulting in the selection of a belief or a course of action among several possible alternative options.(no content)It could be either rational or irrational.

### Types of Decision-Making

**Rational vs. Intuitive:** In situations with higher time pressure, higher stakes, or increased ambiguities, experts may use intuitive decision-making rather than structured approaches, following a recognition-primed decision that fits their experience.

**Consensus Decision-Making:** Consensus decision-making is a group decision-making process in which participants work together to develop proposals for actions that achieve a broad acceptance.

**Data-Informed Decision-Making:** Data-informed decision-making (DIDM) refers to the collection and analysis of data to guide decisions and improve chances of success.

### Challenges in Decision-Making

**Decision Fatigue:** Decision fatigue is the tendency for peoples' decision making to become impaired as a result of having recently taken multiple decisions.

**Analysis Paralysis:** When a group or individual is unable to make it through the problem-solving step on the way to making a decision, they could be experiencing analysis paralysis, which is the state that a person enters where they are unable to make a decision.

### Environmental Factors

More complex environments correlate with higher cognitive function, and cognitive function was greatly affected by the higher measure of environmental complexity, making it easier to think about the situation and make a better decision.

Web search results for query: "Robot"

Links: [{"title":"Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot"},{"title":"I, Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I,_Robot"},{"title":"Robot series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_series"},{"title":"Android (robot) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Android_(robot)"},{"title":"History of robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_robots"},{"title":"Mr. Robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mr._Robot"},{"title":"The Robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Robots"},{"title":"List of Robot Wars robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Robot_Wars_robots"},{"title":"List of fictional robots and androids - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_fictional_robots_and_androids"},{"title":"Rise of the Robots - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rise_of_the_Robots"}]

I've completed a web search for "Robot" and found comprehensive information about the topic. Here's a summary of the results:

## Definition and Overview

A robot is a machine—especially one programmable by a computer—capable of carrying out a complex series of actions automatically.(no content)A robot can be guided by an external control device, or the control may be embedded within.

## Types and Applications

Robots range from humanoids such as Honda's Advanced Step in Innovative Mobility (ASIMO) and TOSY's TOSY Ping Pong Playing Robot (TOPIO) to industrial robots, medical operating robots, patient assist robots, dog therapy robots, collectively programmed swarm robots, UAV drones such as General Atomics MQ-1 Predator, and even microscopic nanorobots.

## History

The term "robot" was first used in a play published by the Czech Karel Čapek in 1920. R.U.R. (Rossum's Universal Robots) was a satire, robots were manufactured biological beings that performed all unpleasant manual labor. According to Čapek, the word was created by his brother Josef from the Czech word robota 'corvée', or in Slovak 'work' or 'labor'.(no content)The first uses of modern robots were in factories as industrial robots. These industrial robots were fixed machines capable of manufacturing tasks which allowed production with less human work.

## Field of Study

The branch of technology that deals with the design, construction, operation, and application of robots, as well as computer systems for their control, sensory feedback, and information processing is robotics.

The search results also include references to robots in science fiction, including Isaac Asimov's works and various TV shows and games featuring robots.

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Ant robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm (novelette) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(novelette)"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Kilobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilobot"},{"title":"S-bot mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-bot_mobile_robot"},{"title":"Sabine Hauert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabine_Hauert"},{"title":"Gerardo Beni - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerardo_Beni"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"}]

Here's an overview of **swarm robotics** based on the search results:

## Definition and Principles

Swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots, and takes inspiration from nature such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature like honey bee aggregation.

Key principles of swarm robotics include:
- Robots are autonomous, can interact with surroundings and give feedback to modify the environment, and possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities like wireless transmission systems
- Robots do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish tasks

## History

The phrase "swarm robotics" first appeared in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in the early 2000s. One of the first international projects was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005, which studied swarm behaviors such as collective transport, area coverage, and searching for objects.

## Applications

A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots of different sizes could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely. Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks that demand cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding tasks. Additionally, progress has been made in swarm 3D printing, which is particularly useful for the production of large structures where traditional 3D printing cannot be utilized due to hardware size constraints.

Here's an overview of **swarm robotics** based on the search results:

## Definition and Principles

Swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots, and takes inspiration from nature such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in nature like honey bee aggregation.

Key principles of swarm robotics include:
- Robots are autonomous, can interact with surroundings and give feedback to modify the environment, and possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities like wireless transmission systems
- Robots do not exploit centralized swarm control or global knowledge, and cooperate with each other to accomplish tasks

## History

The phrase "swarm robotics" first appeared in 1991 according to Google Scholar, but research regarding swarm robotics began to grow in the early 2000s. One of the first international projects was the SWARM-BOTS project funded by the European Commission between 2001 and 2005, which studied swarm behaviors such as collective transport, area coverage, and searching for objects.

## Applications

A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots of different sizes could be sent to places that rescue-workers cannot reach safely. Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks that demand cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding tasks. Additionally, progress has been made in swarm 3D printing, which is particularly useful for the production of large structures where traditional 3D printing cannot be utilized due to hardware size constraints.

I found several Wikipedia articles related to human-robot interaction. Here's a summary of the key information:

## Human–Robot Interaction (HRI)

Goals in HRI range from industrial manufacturing through Cobots, medical technology through rehabilitation, autism intervention, and elder care devices, entertainment, human augmentation.

Robots in the human–robot interaction field are not limited to human-like robots: Paro and Kismet are both robots designed to elicit emotional response from humans, and so fall into the category of human–robot interaction.

The subfield of physical human–robot interaction (pHRI) has largely focused on device design to enable people to safely interact with robotic systems, but is increasingly developing algorithmic approaches in an attempt to support fluent and expressive interactions between humans and robotic systems.

## Safety and Ethics

Human–robot interaction prioritizes the safety of humans that interact with potentially dangerous robotics equipment. Safety zones use technologies such as lidar to detect human presence or physical barriers to protect humans by preventing any contact between machine and operator.

## Related Fields

The search also returned information on human-robot collaboration, social robots, humanoid robots, and the International Conference on Human-Robot Interaction, which is "focusing on human-robot interaction with roots in robotics, psychology, cognitive science, human computer interaction (HCI), human factors, artificial intelligence, organizational behavior, anthropology, and other fields".


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Here are the search results for "Robotics":

## Overview

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms.

## Key Components

Robotics combines three aspects of design work: mechanical construction (a frame, form or shape designed to achieve a particular task), electrical components that power and control the machinery, and software (a program for how a robot decides when or how to do something).

## Types of Robots

The field encompasses diverse robot types:

- **Soft Robotics**: Soft robotics is a subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.(no content)In contrast to rigid-bodied robots built from metals, ceramics and hard plastics, the compliance of soft robots can improve their safety when working in close contact with humans.

- **Hexapod Robots**: A hexapod robot is a mechanical vehicle that walks on six legs.

- **Robotic Arms**: A robotic arm is a type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.(no content)Robots can range from humanoids such as Honda's Advanced Step in Innovative Mobility (ASIMO) and TOSY's TOSY Ping Pong Playing Robot (TOPIO) to industrial robots, medical operating robots, patient assist robots, dog therapy robots, collectively programmed swarm robots, UAV drones such as General Atomics MQ-1 Predator, and even microscopic nanorobots.
